content: Several tax options have been proposed to finance health care reform, including restricting itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers and modifying the tax exclusion for employer-provided health care. The Senate Finance Committee provided a list of options for health-related tax provisions, such as increasing taxes on alcoholic beverages and imposing an excise tax on non-diet sweetened beverages. The House and Senate proposed various tax options to finance health care reform, including a surtax on high-income individuals and an excise tax on insurers for high-cost plans. President Obama also suggested a compromise proposal. President Obama proposed a compromise plan based on H.R. 3590, with changes to revenue provisions. The plan delays the tax on high-cost employer plans to 2018, raises exemption thresholds, and adds a 3.8% tax on unearned income for high-income households. The House passed the Senate proposal H.R. 3590 and H.R. 4872 on March 22, 2010. The House passed the Senate proposal H.R. 3590 and H.R. 4872 on March 22, 2010. The President signed H.R. 3590 on March 23 and H.R. 4872 on March 30. Detailed revenue estimates of the tax proposals are in the Appendix, showing differences in effects on behavior and income distribution. The tax changes may impact higher-income taxpayers more heavily (progressive change), equally on all taxpayers (proportional change), or lower-income taxpayers more heavily (regressive change). For example, limits on itemized deductions and taxes on high incomes affect top earners, while health-related income and payroll-tax exclusions impact middle-income brackets more proportionally. Excise taxes tend to be regressive, affecting lower-income classes more. Excise taxes are regressive and impact lower-income classes more heavily. The distributional analysis in the report focuses on the financing mechanism, not the overall effects of health care reform proposals. Despite regressive revenue sources, the proposal may still benefit lower-income individuals. The report also reviews revenue raisers in House and Senate bills, as well as proposals by President Obama and the Obama Administration. The final legislation includes revenue raisers such as increased Medicare tax, fee on health insurance providers, "Cadillac" tax on employer health insurance premiums, and fee on branded drugs. The cellulosic biofuel credit is also a significant provision over a 10-year period. The largest revenue raisers in the legislation include the Medicare tax (44%), Cadillac tax (22%), health insurance fees (14%), and fees on medical devices and corporate reporting (4% each). The cellulosic biofuel provision has expired. The House Ways and Means Committee announced revenue provisions for health care reform, including a tax on high-income individuals. Legislation like the America's Affordable Health Choices Act of 2009 (H.R. 3200) included many of these provisions. The Affordable Health Care for America Act, H.R. 3962, passed in 2009, included modifications to the initial provisions of H.R. 3200. The main changes involved revising the surtax on high-income taxpayers and adding new revenue raisers. The original proposal in H.R. 3200 aimed to generate $583.1 billion for FY2010-FY2014, with $543.9 billion coming from a surtax on individual taxpayers. The Joint Committee on Taxation proposed a surtax on individual taxpayers to generate $543.9 billion. The surtax would be based on adjusted gross income, with rates of 1% to 5.4% for different income levels. The proposal also included a provision to raise $8 billion by adjusting the definition of medical expenses for health savings accounts. The plan proposed raising $8 billion by adjusting the definition of medical expenses for health savings accounts. It also included revenue raisers related to international taxation and tax evasion, such as a delay in the revised allocation of interest for the foreign tax credit, a provision to raise $26.1 billion over 10 years, a provision to raise $7.5 billion related to the use of treaties to avoid U.S. tax, and a provision to codify the economic substance doctrine. The proposal in H.R. 3962 includes revenue raisers such as a 5.4% surtax on incomes over $1 million for joint returns and $500,000 for single taxpayers, raising $460.5 billion over FY2010-FY2014. It also includes provisions related to international taxation and tax evasion introduced in H.R. 3200. The revised allocation of interest for the foreign tax credit in H.R. 3200 was included in other legislation and the current repeal provision is projected to raise $6.0 billion. The economic substance doctrine provision was modified to include penalties for underpayments and is estimated to raise $5.7 billion. Additionally, H.R. 3962 includes restrictions on health-related tax provisions. The plan includes limiting health flexible spending arrangements, increasing penalties for nonqualified distributions from health savings accounts, disallowing deductions for Medicare Part D subsidies, imposing a 2.5% excise tax on medical devices, and requiring information reporting on payments to corporations. The proposal includes extending requirements to corporations for third-party reporting and tax compliance, with a small loss for health benefits extension and a small gain from fees on health plans. It also excludes Indian Tribe health benefits from gross income and includes a tax on the sale of medical devices. The House bill proposal includes a surtax on high-income individuals, targeting the top 1.2% of taxpayers, with the highest surtax affecting only two-tenths of 1% of taxpayers.
